author: Grey Papke
title: Ja‚ÄôMarr Chase has disrespectful take on Chiefs‚Äô defense
text:
Ja‚ÄôMarr Chase has disrespectful take on Chiefs‚Äô defense
Cincinnati Bengals wide receiver Ja‚ÄôMarr Chase is not exactly showing a lot of respect for the Kansas City Chiefs‚Äô defense ahead of their meeting on Sunday.
Chase was dismissive of the Chiefs‚Äô talent, admitting that they run a lot of double teams and are good at nullifying Cincinnati‚Äôs strengths. He implied that scheme was the reason for their success against the Bengals, and argued that they lack any real impact talent on that side of the ball.
Ja‚ÄôMarr Chase had quite the edge after practice today addressing reporters. Said Chiefs don‚Äôt have anyone that stands out on defense. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not really like have a Jalen Ramsey on their squad.‚Äù
[pic.twitter.com/1kurBwcOLF]
‚Äî Mike Petraglia (@Trags)
[December 28, 2023]
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not like they got a Jalen Ramsey on their squad,‚Äù Chase said.
Chase shrugged off the prospect of the Chiefs using his comments as motivation.
Ja‚ÄôMarr Chase didn‚Äôt back track at all when asked about his assessment of Chiefs defense. ‚ÄúThey can take it how they want. I don‚Äôt care. ‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm not Ironman. I can‚Äôt throw the ball to myself. It‚Äôs a team sport.‚Äù
[pic.twitter.com/KmnaKIcLYe]
‚Äî Mike Petraglia (@Trags)
[December 28, 2023]
‚ÄúThey can take it how they want. I don‚Äôt care,‚Äù Chase said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why they double everybody. Because they can‚Äôt do it one-on-one.‚Äù
Chase isn‚Äôt necessarily wrong about the Chiefs lacking big names on defense, particularly in the secondary. However, top cornerback L‚ÄôJarius Sneed has had an excellent season, and Chase did acknowledge him as the best player in that unit.
The Chiefs and Bengals
have developed a strong rivalry in recent years. There may have been some worries that this game might not be quite as intense with the Chiefs struggling and Joe Burrow sidelined for the Bengals, but Chase is doing his part to ensure that is not the case.

author: Jason Kehe
title: The New Hatred of Technology | WIRED
text:
If you buy something using links in our stories, we may earn a commission. This helps support our journalism. [Learn more](https://www.wired.com/2015/11/affiliate-link-policy/). Please also consider [subscribing to WIRED](https://subscribe.wired.com/subscribe/splits/wired/WIR_SELF?source=HCL_WIR_EDIT_HARDCODED_0_COMMERCE_AFFILIATE_ZZ)
People have never been better, here in the Year of Our Simulation 2024, at hating the very forces underlying that [simulation](https://www.wired.com/tag/simulations/)‚Äîat hating, in other words, digital technology itself. And good for them. These everywhere-active tech critics don‚Äôt just rely, for their on-trend position-taking, on vague, nostalgist, technophobic feelings anymore. Now they have research papers to back them up. They have bestsellers by the likes of [Harari](https://www.amazon.com/Nexus-Brief-History-Information-Networks/dp/059373422X/ref=sr_1_2?crid=3FUH9MKJM8OCP&dib=eyJ2IjoiMSJ9.uZ3blUGCyQ7GN-GR1-67mhtJ4TuKa6p_Z6r2AcbaXkCoh1wH6iEnmiB16kZQIFMOlj-tpmCsf1BaUTBsxWPthxB2cRgJA0R9SUjDbPVGUzGzVGMnoak5GqgkTNAFbhxdRfdQmRCsHNQnEQBT5lELJD9LmeiiJfAVsK80vB6j34P-oOfKlkTsei40XebETKdLnRI15I_TYsuqss180kSC4h_CtvVwE2gaRvTrDFDv3sPcWtJP3Iq4xTaiZDBafRYuTCrGwIUuW1ZAHdhFqwf1EEGt4fZmpmlyccnnGOpUb_o.Ni2sWplKUhaRusP4qXiZhS2EjaQWYYZHtorgwoqxtVg&dib_tag=se&keywords=yuval+noah+harari+books&qid=1731437613&sprefix=harari%2Caps%2C454&sr=8-2) and [Haidt](https://www.amazon.com/Anxious-Generation-Rewiring-Childhood-Epidemic/dp/0593655036/ref=sr_1_1?crid=2XC84X2480B3B&dib=eyJ2IjoiMSJ9.v8yHXjrkjHQj2wUrxVTCnHc1BWxUQp-QE_MU05-SXN_9v5bG7su5i2kcZexjOqy9V1GTaZE5fTDKSXx6L_rqyFDzGa_TinlIod3ZtDoEnkn9zjb4VIpaxN7jPUjyi2g7w618g6JWid7tNcGOH18vC5G_BKoTNDacn7GG-0VigQy55HTCRuhmiqp3HFdMK6GiZE3MoRfhXlI3VllK1KHg-YYhb3ATzLKnfEkMjAjKpeo.lj3y1dcMnxKuBxBcL6vU5EdJBxptAXXDSTMtd6EHvFQ&dib_tag=se&keywords=jonathan+haidt+books&qid=1731437632&sprefix=jonathan+haidt%2Caps%2C283&sr=8-1). They have‚Äîpicture their smugness‚Äîstatistics. The kids, I don‚Äôt know if you‚Äôve heard, are killing themselves by the classroomful.
None of this bothers me. Well, teen suicide obviously does, it's horrible, but it‚Äôs not hard to debunk arguments blaming technology. What is hard to debunk, and what does bother me, is the one exception, in my estimation, to this rule: the anti-tech argument offered by the modern-day philosopher.
By philosopher, I don‚Äôt mean some stats-spouting writer of glorified self-help. I mean a deepest-level, ridiculously learned overanalyzer, someone who breaks down problems into their relevant bits so that, when those bits are put back together, nothing looks quite the same. Descartes didn‚Äôt just blurt out ‚ÄúI think, therefore I am‚Äù off the top of his head. He had to go as far into his head as he humanly could, stripping away everything else, before he could arrive at his classic one-liner. (Plus God. People always seem to forget that Descartes, inventor of the so-called rational mind, couldn‚Äôt strip away God.)
For someone trying to marshal a case against technology, then, a Descartes-style line of attack might go something like this: When we go as far into the technology as we can, stripping everything else away and breaking the problem down into its constituent bits, where do we end up? Exactly there, of course: at the literal bits, the 1s and 0s of digital computation. And what do bits tell us about the world? I‚Äôm simplifying here, but pretty much: everything. Cat or dog. Harris or Trump. Black or white. Everyone thinks in binary terms these days. Because that‚Äôs what‚Äôs enforced and entrenched by the dominant machinery.
Or so goes, in brief, the snazziest argument against digital technology: ‚ÄúI binarize,‚Äù the computers teach us, ‚Äútherefore I am.‚Äù Certain technoliterates have been venturing versions of this Theory of Everything for a while now; earlier this year, an English professor at Dartmouth, Aden Evens, published what is, as far as I can tell, its first properly philosophical codification, [The Digital and Its Discontents](https://www.amazon.com/Digital-Its-Discontents-Electronic-Mediations/dp/1517916321/ref=sr_1_1?crid=3KH8OAZ9F6AWP&dib=eyJ2IjoiMSJ9.OWt9UBgziPP6ScSSu1pu1w.ayiOFhWRIKajKya7U6Nj34uCBU4rn2-OClZiyN0Yhok&dib_tag=se&keywords=digital+and+discontents+aden+evens&qid=1731437649&sprefix=digital+and+discontents+aden+eve%2Caps%2C258&sr=8-1). I‚Äôve chatted a bit with Evens. Nice guy. Not a technophobe, he claims, but still: It‚Äôs clear he‚Äôs world-historically distressed by digital life, and he roots that distress in the fundaments of the technology.
I might‚Äôve agreed, [once](https://www.wired.com/story/why-you-hate-media-technically-speaking/). Now, as I say: I‚Äôm bothered. I‚Äôm unsatisfied. The more I think about the technophilosophy of Evens et al., the less I want to accept it. Two reasons for my dissatisfaction, I think. One: Since when do the base units of anything dictate the entirety of its higher-level expression? Genes, the base units of life, only account for some submajority percentage of how we develop and behave. Quantum-mechanical phenomena, the base units of physics, have no bearing on my physical actions. (Otherwise I‚Äôd be walking through walls‚Äîwhen I wasn‚Äôt, half the time, being dead.) So why must binary digits define, for all time, the limits of computation, and our experience of it? New behaviors always have a way, when complex systems interact, of mysteriously emerging. Nowhere in the individual bird can you find the flocking algorithm! Turing himself said you can‚Äôt look at computer code and know, completely, what‚Äôll happen.
And two: Blaming technology‚Äôs discontents on the 1s and 0s treats the digital as an endpoint, as some sort of logical conclusion to the history of human thought‚Äîas if humanity, as Evens suggests, had finally achieved the dreams of an Enlightened rationality. There‚Äôs no reason to believe such a thing. Computing was, for most of its history, not digital. And, if [predictions about an analog comeback](https://www.wired.com/story/unbelievable-zombie-comeback-analog-computing/) are right, it won‚Äôt stay purely digital for much longer. I‚Äôm not here to say whether computer scientists should or shouldn‚Äôt be evolving chips analogically, only to say that, were it to happen, it‚Äôd be silly to claim that all the binarisms of modern existence, so thoroughly inculcated in us by our digitized machinery, would suddenly collapse into nuance and glorious analog complexity. We invent technology. Technology doesn‚Äôt invent us.
Unless, of course, we really are living in a simulation. Sometimes [I suspect we are](https://www.wired.com/story/living-in-a-simulation/). Two more things to say about that. One: Our simulation is definitely running on analog chips. And two: We‚Äôre back to Descartes. He thought, therefore he was, but he couldn‚Äôt quite exist separate from that which can‚Äôt be stripped away: his simulator, his God. To hate technology is to hate creation itself.
Time Travel
Uh oh, in my [2022 piece about the simulation argument](https://www.wired.com/story/living-in-a-simulation/), I suggested that reality is boilable-down to bits: ‚ÄúIn the beginning, after all, God created light and darkness,‚Äù I wrote. ‚ÄúTranslation: The simulator created 1s and 0s.‚Äù Decide for yourself how literal I was being.
Ask Me One Thing
One reader wants to know how nice we should be to the artificial intelligences. Should we thank chatbots? Not kick robots? Say hello and goodbye to self-driving cars? It‚Äôs a modern-day version of Pascal‚Äôs famous wager: Believe in God just in case. Let me introduce WIRED‚Äôs Wager: Respect the computers just in case.
You can submit questions to [mail@wired.com](mailto:mail@wired.com?subject=ASK%20LEVY). Write ASK LEVY in the subject line.
End Times Chronicle
Did you read this newsletter all the way through? According to The Atlantic, [nobody reads anymore](https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2024/11/the-elite-college-students-who-cant-read-books/679945/). How do they know? I don‚Äôt know. I didn‚Äôt read it.
Last but Not Least
The US has long been trying to ‚Äúreshore‚Äù chipmaking. Here‚Äôs a look inside [Intel‚Äôs colossal effort](https://www.wired.com/story/the-wired-guide-to-protecting-yourself-from-government-surveillance/) to build a fab in Ohio.
At [this billion-dollar startup](https://www.wired.com/story/physical-intelligence-ai-robotics-startup/), robots are finally getting back to the business of folding laundry.
Roughly 40 percent of the posts on the blogging site Medium [are AI slop](https://www.wired.com/story/ai-generated-medium-posts-content-moderation/), according to two independent analyses.
Feeling twitchy? Two hotshot security reporters just dropped the WIRED guide to [protecting yourself](https://www.wired.com/story/the-wired-guide-to-protecting-yourself-from-government-surveillance/) from America‚Äôs digital surveillance machine.
Don't miss future subscriber-only editions of this column. [Subscribe to WIRED (50% off for Plaintext readers)](https://subscribe.wired.com/subscribe/splits/wired/WIR_STEVEN_LEVY?source=EDT_WIR_ARTICLE_SUBSCRIBE_LINK_0_STEVEN_LEVY_ZZ) today.

author: Erum Salam
title: Huge waves pound California coast as powerful storms pass through | California | The Guardian
text:
Unusually large waves are hitting California shores as powerful storms pass through the region.
Waves over 20ft high poured over seawalls and the tops of low cliffs along the Pacific coast, flooding nearby streets and leaving many injured. In a video taken on Thursday morning by Ventura native Colin Hogue, people are seen fleeing Pierpont beach ‚Äì just north of Los Angeles ‚Äì as a monstrous rogue wave engulfs the area.
Severe rainstorms hit southern California, with more to come
Read more Hogue called the scene ‚Äúhorrific‚Äù.
‚ÄúThere was a lot of screaming, a lot of yelling, a lot of cussing. I didn‚Äôt know how far this was going to go,‚Äù Hogue said. ‚ÄúI thought to myself ‚Äòthis is a tsunami.‚Äô‚Äù
The Ventura county fire department reported eight people were transported to local hospitals after coming in close contact with the massive wave.
Andy Vansciver, a VCFD firefighter, told KTLA5: ‚ÄúI think a lot of lessons were learned today when you look at that video of the importance of heeding on to the warnings of giving the ocean some respect.‚Äù
Large debris has led to road closures in the path of the waves. As a result, a coastal flood advisory and a high surf warning are in effect until Friday for more than 6 million people in parts of California and Oregon.
Evacuation warnings were also issued in counties along the coast of the state, including Santa Cruz, Marin and Ventura.
In Santa Cruz, the local news station KSBW Action News 8 captured a powerful wave that flung two nearby children into a bush.
This video is a prime example of why we urge people to stay AWAY from the water! Waves can EASILY knock people down and sweep them away.
Use extreme caution! These waves are breaking at 28-33' and can easily breach the tops of low cliffs or seawalls like those seen here. #CAwx https://t.co/iN2dzUfaoX
‚Äî NWS Bay Area üåâ (@NWSBayArea) December 28, 2023 The worst is yet to come.
On Friday morning, the National Weather Service issued a warning: ‚ÄúWidespread precipitation will spread across the region today through Saturday, with the heaviest expected tonight. Be prepared for slick roads and a longer than normal commute. Slow down on wet roads! #cawx ‚Äù
Widespread precipitation will spread across the region today through Saturday, with the heaviest expected tonight. Be prepared for slick roads and a longer than normal commute. Slow down on wet roads! #cawx pic.twitter.com/D1dMkMu6ra
‚Äî NWS Sacramento (@NWSSacramento) December 29, 2023 Explore more on these topics California US weather news
Reuse this content

author: @ctvottawa
title: Pet food bank demand on the rise in Ottawa | CTV News
text: Many people consider pets to be part of the family, and affordability challenges can create problems filling bowls on the floor as much as they do filling plates on the table. The Ottawa Humane Society (OHS) operates a pet food bank at its West Hunt Club headquarters. Pop-up locations operate regularly as well. OHS president and CEO Sharon Miko tells Newstalk 580 CFRA's Ottawa at Work with Patricia Boal demand for the service continues to grow. More information is available online. But when the couple looked around, they say a pack of eight coyotes surrounded them, picked Kahlua up and ran off with him. A Canadian airline is changing its check-in deadline for all flights. Here's why Travellers will have to check in 15 minutes earlier than usual according to Air Canada's new cutoff time for all flights. Winnipeg - Bus drops off Winnipeg school-aged kids at wrong locations after glitch with school division‚Äôs new app A Winnipeg mother said glitches with a new app rolled out by Pembina Trails School Division to assist with scheduling bussing for students lead to her five and seven-year-old sons being left stranded on their street alone. - 'Principal architect' of Morrisseau mass forgeries sentenced to five years in prison Mass forgeries of Indigenous artist Norval Morrisseau's paintings have caused irreparable harm to the trailblazer's legacy -- and to First Nations art writ large, an Ontario judge acknowledged Thursday in sentencing one of the ringleaders of a sprawling fraud scheme. - IIU investigating after man shot by RCMP in rural Manitoba Manitoba's police watchdog is now investigating after an RCMP officer shot a man outside a home in the RM of Macdonald.
